definitions.definition: to keep somebody/something inside the limits of a particular activity, subject, area, etc.
definitions.sensetop: be confined to (doing) somethingconfine yourself to (doing) somethingbe confined + adv./prep.

examples.text: The work will not be confined to the Glasgow area.
I will confine myself to looking at the period from 1900 to 1916.
Here the river is confined in a narrow channel.
Let's confine our attention to the problem of truancy.
Not all horror stories are safely confined to the television set or movie screen.
Poverty and deprivation are by no means confined to the north of the country.
The discussion will be confined largely to general principles.
They confined themselves to purely economic matters.
These small mammals are generally confined to the south of the island.

definitions.definition: to keep a person or an animal in a small or closed space

examples.text: Keep the dog confined in a suitable travelling cage.
The soldiers concerned were **confined to barracks** (= had to stay in the , as a punishment).

definitions.definition: to have to stay in bed, in a wheelchair, etc.
definitions.sensetop: be confined to bed, a wheelchair, etc.

examples.text: She was confined to bed with the flu.
He was confined to a wheelchair after the accident.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (as a noun): from French confins (plural noun), from Latin confinia, from confinis ‘bordering’, from con- ‘together’ + finis ‘end, limit’ (plural fines ‘territory’). The verb senses are from French confiner, based on Latin confinis.
